Rail workers are somewhat unique in that they aren‚Äôt protected by the National Labor Relations Act, which protects workers‚Äô right to strike at any time if their contract is expired. Instead, they are covered by the Railway Labor Act (RLA), an earlier law that requires workers to navigate a convoluted process before they are allowed to strike.
Rail workers, claiming deteriorating working conditions, have been negotiating a new contract  with railroad companies for
. A key sticking point has been the matter of paid sick leave ‚Äî because currently, workers
Railroad companies have been slashing their workforces for years, leaving workers on call for days and weeks on end with zero days of paid sick leave. Workers

As contract negotiations ground to a halt this summer, Biden convened an emergency board in July to make recommendations to the railroad bosses and union negotiators on a path forward.

But when Biden‚Äôs board came up with a tentative agreement in September, it didn‚Äôt even come close to meeting the workers‚Äô paid sick leave demands ‚Äî only including a single day of paid sick leave.
Meanwhile, the railroad companies don‚Äôt believe workers who make the industry run deserve any credit for their profitability, according to Biden‚Äôs emergency board.
‚ÄúThe carriers maintain that capital investment and risk are the reasons for their profits, not any contributions by labor,‚Äù the board wrote in its August
. ‚ÄúThe carriers further argue that there is no correlation historically between high profits and higher compensation, either in the freight rail industry or more generally.‚Äù

, the country‚Äôs largest rail union ‚Äî the Sheet Metal, Air, Rail, and Transport Workers‚Äô Transportation Division, representing 28,000 railroad workers ‚Äî voted to reject the proposed agreement. This followed ‚Äúno‚Äù votes on the deal from the Brotherhood of Railway Signalmen, the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees-Teamsters, and the International Brotherhood of Boilermakers ‚Äî unions that together represent nearly 60,000 of the 100,000 union rail workers who could go on strike if no agreement is reached.

This demand is in stark contradistinction to Biden‚Äôs response to Congress‚Äô actions in 1992 that forced railroad workers back to work under similar circumstances.
